title: Extractive QA with multiple answers
body:
Hello, I am new to txtai and I want to know if I can have a list of results with the QA approach.

My code is:

```
context = ["The doctor administered a 7g dose of Acetarsol and a 16mg dose of Ibuprofen",
           "The patient took one Alosetron tablet"]


queries = ["What is the drug taken?", "What is the dose?"]

questions = Questions(path=("sultan/BioM-ELECTRA-Large-SQuAD2-BioASQ8B", tokenizer), gpu=True)
results = [questions([question] * len(context), context) for question in queries]
results.append(context)

pd.DataFrame(list(zip(*results)), columns=["Drug", "Dose", "Text"])
```

I would like to have this result.
| Drug  | Dose | Text
| ------------- | ------------- | ------------- |
| Acetarsol  | 7g | The doctor administered a 7g dose of Acetarsol and a 16mg dose of Ibuprofen
| Ibuprofen  | 16mg  | The doctor administered a 7g dose of Acetarsol and a 16mg dose of Ibuprofen
| Alosetron  | None  | The patient took one Alosetron tablet

thank you for your help

title: Fix issue with ORDER BY case sensitivity
body:
An issue was discovered regarding case sensitivity for `ORDER BY` clauses. Specifically the `BY` portion of the clause. 

Update the code to make a case insensitive comparison for the `BY` token.

title: Allow searching for images
body:
At the moment the `similar` clause only allows searching for text. It would be useful to extend this to images also.
@davidmezzetti on Slack suggested using something like `similar(image:///PATH)`.


As a workaround for anyone else wanting to search by images, I did notice you can do it right now, but you can't use the SQL syntax. 
That is, you can search the whole index for the closest entry, but can't filter entries out.
This functionality isn't documented on `txtai`, it just works as a side-effect of CLIP.
You can also search for embeddings directly.

For example:
```python
import requests
from sentence_transformers import SentenceTransformer
from PIL import Image
from txtai.embeddings import Embeddings

texts = ["a picture of a cat", "a painting of a dog"]
texts_index = [(i, t, None) for i, t in enumerate(texts)]

embeddings = Embeddings({"method": "sentence-transformers", "path": "sentence-transformers/clip-ViT-B-32", "content": True})
embeddings.index(texts_index)

url = "https://cataas.com/cat"
r = requests.get(url, stream=True)
im = Image.open(r.raw).convert("RGB")

# search image directly
print(embeddings.search(im, 2))

# search embeddings
model = SentenceTransformer('clip-ViT-B-32')
im_emb = model.encode(im)
print(embeddings.search(im_emb, 2))
```
outputs
```text
[{'id': '0', 'text': 'a picture of a cat', 'score': 0.25348278880119324}, {'id': '1', 'text': 'a painting of a dog', 'score': 0.18208511173725128}]
[{'id': '0', 'text': 'a picture of a cat', 'score': 0.25348278880119324}, {'id': '1', 'text': 'a painting of a dog', 'score': 0.18208511173725128}]
```

title: Normalize BM25 and TF-IDF scores
body:
BM25 and TF-IDF scores are unbounded. They will continue to grow as the match improves. This change adds a flag to normalize scores from 0 - 1.

This method will calculate an average score using the average document length, average frequency and average idf score. A max score will then be calculated as `4 * average score`. Lastly, scores will be scaled between 0 to 1 using the range of 0 to max score. 

Formulas for this shown below.

```python
average = score(average frequency, average idf, average document length)
max = 4 * average
score = score / max
```

title: Fix bug with embeddings functions and application config
body:
As reported in #394, applications fail when using semantic graphs through application configuration.

Function resolution in applications should only update functions if they are callable functions, pipelines or workflows. Otherwise, resolution errors should be skipped under the assumption that the function will be resolved in the embeddings instance.

title: Improve batchtransform performance
body:
Currently, `embeddings.batchtransform` calls the underlying vector model once per row. There have been recent changes to the vectors package that can batch encode large arrays. This should be utilized to improve performance.

This will vastly improve the indexing performance of semantic graphs.

title: Pass evaluation metrics to underlying Trainer
body: Currently, HFTrainer has no way to compute custom evaluation metrics. A metrics parameter should be added that is passed along to the underlying Trainer instance.

title: Modified logger configuration in __init__.py (libraries shouldn't modify root logger)
body:
Very minor tweak suggested to`__init__.py` only.

I've been getting duplicate log messages when I import `txtai` into my code.  It turns out txtai modifies Python's root logger in it's `__init__.py` using `logging.basicConfig()`.  However it is recommended that "importable" libraries do not configure log handlers/formatters, and that they should leave that to the "application" code.

So I've edited this line to better reflect the recommendations from the [official python docs](https://docs.python.org/3/howto/logging.html#configuring-logging-for-a-library).

title: Allow searching by embedding
body: I'd like to search directly by an embedding I already have (not a string). Quick-fix is to check [here](https://github.com/neuml/txtai/blob/master/src/python/txtai/embeddings/search.py#L73) if the query is a string or nparray. If latter, skip the transform() step

title: Allow save embeddings (the tmpfile.npy); or option to return embeddings with query
body:
I'd like to work with the actual numpy embeddings (the ones [buffered here](https://github.com/neuml/txtai/blob/master/src/python/txtai/embeddings/base.py#L113)). Context on why later. I thought it was [storevectors](https://github.com/neuml/txtai/blob/master/src/python/txtai/embeddings/base.py#L492), but that looks to save the transformers model; and the [embeddings file](https://github.com/neuml/txtai/blob/master/src/python/txtai/embeddings/base.py#L503) is the ANN index. I see two solutions: add a `vector` field to the SQL search query (eg, `select id, text, vector from txtai`) which will run `faiss.reconstruct()` [here](https://github.com/neuml/txtai/blob/master/src/python/txtai/ann/faiss.py#L59). I don't know how reconstruct works, but I see it used for that purpose [in haystack](https://github.com/deepset-ai/haystack/blob/main/haystack/document_stores/faiss.py#L427). My concern is that this solution is lossy (does reconstruct try to regenerate the original vector?). Also you'd have to have an equivalent for the other ANNs. So I think a better approach is:

Add another config like `save_actual_embeddings`, which will copy over the tmpfile.npy. BUT, it would be hard to map the original IDs in - unless you did something dirty like the first column of the numpy array is the id (text, where the other columns are floats). I think a better approach is to save it as Pandas (or Feather / Arrow / whatever), with an ID column and vector column. I think this could be a simple add. But you could take it even further and scrap sqlite, just use the Pandas dataframe (wherein you can do sql-like queries, fields, etc) - two birds.

--- 
The context (feel free to skip). I'm building search. When they search, they get their search results like normal. But also, in the side bar there are a bunch of resources related to the _results_ of their search. So it would take the vectors of all the returned results, `np.mean()` them, then send them to the various resource searches. Specifically it's a journal app, and a user will search through past entries. The result of that search will be say 10 entries. `np.mean(10_entry_vectors)` now goes to book-search, therapist-search, etc. So I don't want to search books/therapists from their query, but from their entries which result from their query. I also want to cluster their resultant entries (I still need to explore txtai's graph feature), for which I'd need the vectors). And finally (I'll submit a separate ticket, I'd like to search directly by vector, not text (using said mean).

title: Add default configuration for Embeddings
body: Embeddings should behave like pipelines in that an instance can be created with no configuration. A default model will be used in this case. The best model to choose as a default is `sentence-transformers/all-MiniLM-L6-v2`

title: Transcription pipeline improvements
body:
Bring the functionality of the transcription pipeline up to the level of the translation and text-to-speech pipelines.

- Supporting streaming processing of large inputs. Add parameter to chunk input into chunk second segments.
- Add parameter to join those chunks back together or to return the chunks
- Convert stereo audio to mono as models only support mono audio
- Resample audio to target sampling rate of model. This is already being done by the HF pipeline but it relies on torchaudio. Use SciPy and add it as a dependency.

title: Add TextToSpeech Notebook
body: Add TextToSpeech Notebook

title: Modify transcription pipeline to accept raw waveform data
body: Currently, the transcription pipeline assumes inputs are audio files. Modify the pipeline to also accept raw waveform data accompanied by a sample rate.

title: Add TextToSpeech pipeline
body:
Text To Speech (TTS) models have made great strides in quality over the last few years. Unfortunately, it's not easy to use these libraries without installing a large number of dependencies.

This task will add a new TextToSpeech pipeline with the following objectives:

- Fast performance both on CPU and GPU
- Ability to batch large text values and stream it through the model
- Minimal install footprint
- All dependencies must be Apache 2.0 compatible

A new project, [ttstokenizer](https://github.com/neuml/ttstokenizer) was created to standardize the tokenization of English text for speech generation. This project builds on excellent prior work, adding logic to make it easier to use. 

[ESPnet](https://github.com/espnet/espnet) has a number of high quality TTS models available on the Hugging Face hub. They have also created a great library for exporting those to ONNX, [espnet_onnx](https://github.com/espnet/espnet_onnx).

Two models have been converted to ONNX and uploaded to the HF Hub:

- [ljspeech-jets-onnx](https://huggingface.co/NeuML/ljspeech-jets-onnx)
- [ljspeech-vits-onnx](https://huggingface.co/NeuML/ljspeech-vits-onnx)

title: Update data package to handle label arrays
body:
Currently, the data package assumes each label value is a single numeric value. This leads to inefficient structuring for data with multiple labels, as a new row would be necessary for each label. 

Add support for `text, [labels]`.

title: Split pipeline extras by function area
body:
Currently, the pipeline extra installs all dependencies for all pipelines. Given the growth of pipelines, this is installing a lot of dependencies when a developer may only want to use one function area.

This change will add additional extras for `pipeline-audio`, `pipeline-data`, `pipeline-image`, `pipeline-text`, and `pipeline-train`. The `pipeline` extra will still be available and operate the same.

title: Store and query by data when `content: False`
body:
I am trying to index a few million images totaling a few Terabytes in size for a similarity search.

When I set Embeddings' `content` to `True`, I am able to store and query data with each image record (user_id and a few other fields to filter the similarity search by):
```
embeddings = Embeddings({"batch": 2, "encodebatch": 2, "method": "sentence-transformers", "path": "sentence-transformers/clip-ViT-B-32", "content": True, "objects": "image" })
```

However, when I set `content: false` I only get the ID and score back and can no longer use SQL queries to query the data.

I believe this behavior is by design but is there any way to have the SQL store/query when content is set to false?

(The reason why `content: True` is not a good option for me is because the images total in the Terabytes and I don't wish to duplicate that much data)

Thanks for creating the library, it definitely makes working with these models much easier.

body:
The translation pipeline calls the Hugging Face API and lists all available models. Those models are then filtered for models starting with `Helsinki-NLP`.

The API offers a way to provide an `author` filter and should be used instead. This is more efficient and a better use of resources.

title: Update build script and tests to address issues with latest version of FastAPI
body:
FastAPI 0.87.0 upgraded to the latest version of Starlette which now requires the `httpx` library. Both FastAPI and Starlette have `httpx` as an optional dependency given it's only required when using the TestClient.

The tests are currently broken due to this change. To fix the issue, `http` should be added as a dev dependency. 

Details on this change can be found here: https://github.com/tiangolo/fastapi/releases/tag/0.87.0

title: Fix issue with select distinct
body:
`select distinct` queries aren't being interpreted correctly. For example:

```python
embeddings.search("select distinct id, text from txtai where similar('test')")
```

doesn't return the distinct id/text rows. There is most likely an issue with the query preprocessor and the `distinct` keyword.

In the meantime, the following workaround can be used:

```python
embeddings.search("select distinct(id || text), id, text from txtai where similar('test')")
```

title: Is there any relation between embedding data and /similarity API ?
body:
I have a lot of test data and embedding data /add-ed and /upsert-ed in a system,
In that system when I do /search request 

(with an SQL query like 
Select id,text, score, data from txtai where similar("what is the specialtiy of this ?",'8000') AND something ='something' ... )

 it takes around 0 to 3 seconds to pick 10 results. I'm ok with that(because it may take time since the number data I have stored is larger like thousands of text documents' paragraphs extracted and stored ).

I think only /search API or /batchsearch API is gonna look into the 1000s of paragraphs to find the response. But /similarity API is not like them... (please correct me if I'm wrong) Because when we use http://localhost:8000/similarity we ourselves giving the list of texts and question in the request body.. and txtai is gonna return the list of id,score pairs only.

What I'm trying to say is, when I did the following (POST) request by port forwarding the txtAI from a Linux system that already has a lot of embeddings stored. It took 600ms to 1200ms to get the response (I checked this timing by sending requests few more times using Postman .)

curl   -X POST "http://localhost:8000/similarity"  -H "Content-Type: application/json"  -d '{"query": "feel good story", "texts": ["Maine man wins $1M from $25 lottery ticket", "Dont sacrifice slower friends in a bear attack"]}'

But when I do the same in a fresh system or system with lesser embedding data, it is only taking 50ms or lesser than that to find the response.

Is there any relation between embedding data and /similarity API ?

(For a text list with 2 or 3 sentence, it is fine to take 600 to 1200 ms, but when I try to do the same with 100s of texts and 1 question.. it is taking 13 or more seconds)

My usecase is to do the /similarity operarion and calculate id,score for 100s of texts and 1 question in 1 to 3 seconds or lesser.
I could achieve it in a system having lesser trained(embedding) data but not in the other case

So that's why I want to know, Is there any relation between embedding data and /similarity API ?

Actually I'm having a semantic search program in golang in which I'm using txtAI's APIs to perform searching, I'm making use of /search and /similarity APIs to fetch the results for the user query. Which is like after getting  the 10 results from /search , I will be doing /similarity operation on each of 10 results's metadata keywords (that I have trained along with the "text" and "id" at the time of indexing them which will be in the "data" field ) following this approach I could improve the search result accuracy  that I have expected,  but the time it takes is more than 13 seconds when I have more keywords or tags in the "data" field.. I noticed that this time taken is only because of the /similarity API.
Im pointing out the same in the following to make it clear to understand,
1. Do /search with a limit 10, Get 10 results and scores
2. Recalculate each result's score - 1 by 1 by.. finding /similarity between "user question"(query) and metadata content(texts) of each result - get the list of id and scores. 
3. Merge these /similarity scores with /search scores and compute the scores again.
4. Now sort the results based on score again
5. Return 10 results to user.

Please suggest me an efficient way to improve the search speed and search accuracy.

title: Create compression package

title: Add Unsupervised Learning/Domain Adaptation Pipelines
body:
I was quite happy to see the new Cross Encoder support in the Similarity Pipeline given how well it has ranked in various tests - e.g. from [this paper](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2104.08663.pdf) from Nils Reimer of SBERT and the SBERT documentation's recommendations for BM25 Retrieval + CE Re-Ranking. However, I'm finding it to be rather slow, even with a small number of documents from the initial BM25 step. 

Nils subsequently published [this paper](https://arxiv.org/abs/2112.07577) about a new technique, Generative Pseudo Labelling (GPL), for unsupervised label generation for any text corpus which ultimately generates a fine-tuned embedding model. 

It is nearly as relevant as BM25 + Cross Encoder Re-Ranking, particularly when combined with TSDAE (for "denoising"/precleaning text)
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/88559987/198844419-2de88308-4119-4548-8d64-3594696c9932.png)

but it would be much faster at query-time than CE Re-Ranking (table from the first paper linked above - presumably would be similar to other embedding models, eg 200ms):
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/88559987/198844960-e45403e4-ad4c-43cc-ad57-01c073509fc5.png)

This would surely be expensive to pre-generate, but so are most dense vector embeddings and that's generally acceptable because it is done one time. The important part is the cross encoder-level relevance with normal bi-encoder speed. 

I'm not sure what the best approach would be to incorporate into txtai, but it seems like TSDAE could be an optional pre-processing pipeline and then GPL could be an augmentation to the Labels pipeline (which seems to require you to pre-suggest labels rather than have them generated automatically and the HFTrainer pipeline. 

And, perhaps, the GPL pipeline could be made up of individual pipeline components for the 3 steps:
1. Query generation
2. Negative Mining
3. Pseudo Labelling

(I'm not as sure about step 2 and 3, but the 1st step for Query Generation would certainly be a useful standalone Pipeline)

title: CVE-2007-4559 Patch
body:
# Patching CVE-2007-4559

Hi, we are security researchers from the Advanced Research Center at [Trellix](https://www.trellix.com). We have began a campaign to patch a widespread bug named CVE-2007-4559. CVE-2007-4559 is a 15 year old bug in the Python tarfile package. By using extract() or extractall() on a tarfile object without sanitizing input, a maliciously crafted .tar file could perform a directory path traversal attack. We found at least one unsantized extractall() in your codebase and are providing a patch for you via pull request. The patch essentially checks to see if all tarfile members will be extracted safely and throws an exception otherwise. We encourage you to use this patch or your own solution to secure against CVE-2007-4559. Further technical information about the vulnerability can be found in this [blog](https://www.trellix.com/en-us/about/newsroom/stories/research/tarfile-exploiting-the-world.html).

If you have further questions you may contact us through this projects lead researcher [Kasimir Schulz](mailto:kasimir.schulz@trellix.com).

title: Fix issue with Application autosequencing
body:
Currently, embeddings.count() is used for id auto sequencing. This could result in inadvertently replacing an existing record if an id is deleted. 

For example say the ids `0, 1, 2, 3` were inserted and then `0` was deleted. The next insert would use self.count() which would be 3 (1, 2, 3) and replace 3 resulting in an index with only 3 entries instead of 4.

The embeddings.config["offset"] should be used instead of count() as the offset is incremented for every insert.

title: Update scoring algorithms
body:
txtai's scoring algorithms are BM25, TF-IDF and SIF. Scoring methods are used with an embeddings instance when paired with a word vectors model. They are not used with sentence transformers models. Scoring models can be used directly. 

The algorithms for these scoring methods should match the most common implementations of each algorithm. Sync scoring methods with the following formulas and constants.

**1. TF-IDF**
 ```
 idf  = log((numdocs + 1) / (docfreq + 1)) + 1
 score = idf * sqrt(tf) * (1/sqrt(length))
 ```
 
 References:
 - https://opensourceconnections.com/blog/2015/10/16/bm25-the-next-generation-of-lucene-relevation/
 - https://github.com/apache/lucene/blob/main/lucene/core/src/java/org/apache/lucene/search/similarities/ClassicSimilarity.java
 - https://scikit-learn.org/stable/modules/generated/sklearn.feature_extraction.text.TfidfTransformer.html
 - https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tf%E2%80%93idf#Inverse_document_frequency
   
**2. BM25**
```
k1 = 1.2, b = 0.75
idf = log(1 + (numdocs - docfreq + 0.5) / (docfreq + 0.5))
k = k1 * ((1 - b) + b * length / avgdl)
score = idf * (tf * (k1 + 1)) / (tf + k)
```

References:
- https://opensourceconnections.com/blog/2015/10/16/bm25-the-next-generation-of-lucene-relevation/
- https://github.com/apache/lucene/blob/main/lucene/core/src/java/org/apache/lucene/search/similarities/BM25Similarity.java
- https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Okapi_BM25
   
**3. SIF**
```
a = 1e-3
score = a / (a + docFreq / numTokens)
```

References:
- https://github.com/PrincetonML/SIF/blob/master/src/data_io.py#L271

title: Elasticsearch example updates
body: Updating some examples to Elasticsearch 8.4. I also renamed the datasets and indices because I run them all from one cloned directory in vscode and the datasets were all named articles

title: update syntax for ES 8.x
body: ES 8.x deprecated the `body` parameter, in favour of passing parameters directly to the query. I'm not sure if this will work retroactively with ES 7.x, but the python elasticsearch that is installed in this Example is for the most recent version (8.4.2 as of now).

title: Error loading compressed indexes in console
body:
Currently, the console `load` command assumes a file is YAML. When trying to load a compressed index, an error is raised.

A check should be added to confirm the file is YAML. Otherwise, try loading as an embeddings index. If both fail, an error should be raised.

title: Fix docker command "--it"
body:
Hi David,

I ran into this while I was playing with txtai.

The current command generates

```
unknown flag: --it
See 'docker run --help'
```
when executing on Linux.

title: Update audio transcription notebook to include example with OpenAI Whisper
body: [OpenAI Whisper](https://github.com/openai/whisper) was released yesterday, dramatically improving audio transcription quality. Update the audio transcription pipeline notebook to show how it can be used currently with txtai.

title: Allow custom ann, database and graph instances
body:
Currently, txtai only supports a limited number of ANN (Faiss, HNSW, Annoy), Database (SQLite) and Graph (NetworkX) backends. This change will allow setting each of these to external implementations.

Not all backends will be supported directly in txtai for a number of reasons, especially for newer data store implementations given the dynamic nature of change. Anyone willing to maintain a backend now has a means to use that with txtai, provided they implement the relevant interface.

To get an idea of what this means with this change, txtai can now support a Weaviate ANN index, a Cloud RDBMS for structured data and Neo4j as the graph store.

title: Add graph documentation
body: Update documentation with graph configuration and details.

title: Can't install txtai on AWS EC2 box
body:
Installation is killed while installing txtai via pip in AWS Ubuntu EC2.

Solution:
```
pip install txtai --no-cache-dir
```

title: Add notebook covering Semantic Graphs
body: Add notebook covering Semantic Graphs

title: Fix cached_path error with transformers v4.22
body:
Transformers v4.22 removed the `cached_path` method with https://github.com/huggingface/transformers/pull/18497.

This is resulting in the following error when running with transformers==4.22.0

```
ImportError: cannot import name 'cached_path' from 'transformers.file_utils'
```

The translation pipeline needs to be updated with an equivalent way to run `cached_path` like functionality for files not on the Hugging Face Hub.

The workaround for txtai < 5.0 is to pin transformers to <= 4.21.3.

title: Add semantic graph component
body:
One of the main use cases of txtai is semantic search over a corpus of data. Semantic search has an understanding of natural language and identifies results that have the same meaning, not necessarily the same keywords. 

This task will use the relationships inherently learned within an embeddings corpus to build a semantic graph. Semantic graphs, also known as knowledge graphs or semantic networks, build a graph network with semantic relationships between the nodes.

The txtai graph instance will consist of nodes and edges, backed by a graph framework or database. The following initial set of features will be supported.

- Explore direct and indirect neighbors of nodes. Each node is connected to it's top N most similar neighbors. Those neighbors the same to form a network of nodes.
- Walk the graph to find paths between nodes. See how connected the dataset is.
- Run graph analysis methods such as node centrality and page rank to find the most important nodes in a dataset
- Group nodes using community detection algorithms to provide topic modeling
- Work with any data Embeddings supports (text, images...)
- Ability to plug-in different graph frameworks or graph database backends

This task is just the beginning and will be a major area of growth in coming txtai releases.

title: Add SQL expression columns
body:
Add the ability to alias a SQL expression as a column. For example a column named `idtext` as `id + text`. This change is particularly useful in aliasing function calls as columns.

A future task will add the ability to build expression indexes with this framework and vastly improve expression performance.

title: Calling scoring.index with no tokens parsed results in error
body: Currently, if `scoring.index` is called when no tokens are parsed an exception is raised. This condition should be properly handled with the index process aborting when no tokens parsed.

title: Update workflow documentation to note generator execution
body:
Workflows run as generator functions given they support processing large, streaming datasets. This can be confusing if you run `workflow(elements)` without consuming the output, nothing happens.

This issue will update the documentation to make it clear that generator outputs must be consumed for execution to occur.

title: Support non-text document elements in Applications
body: Currently, the document.add method logic assumes data elements are text. This logic should be consistent with Embeddings and support non-text data (i.e. audio, images etc) provided the vector model supports it.

title: Update ANN package to make terminology more consistent
body: Currently, the ANN package has some naming inconsistencies. This change will make naming consistent across the different ANN backends.

title: Update console to conditionally import library
body: Currently, the Console class imports rich without a conditional import wrapper. Wrapping this as a conditional import will show a better error message when the console extra is not installed.

title: Read authentication parameters from storage task
body:
Currently, the storage task does not support reading authentication parameters. While this task is using the same library as embeddings cloud storage (Apache Libcloud), this is effectively limiting the task to only working with local storage.

This change will add the following parameters to the storage task (as shown in the embeddings cloud storage config reader).

```python
# Get driver for provider
driver = get_driver(config["provider"])

# Get client connection
client = driver(
  config.get("key", os.environ.get("ACCESS_KEY")),
  config.get("secret", os.environ.get("ACCESS_SECRET")),
  host=config.get("host"),
  port=config.get("port"),
  token=config.get("token"),
  region=config.get("region")
)
```

title: Support for Qdrant as an embedding backend
body:
Hi @davidmezzetti, thanks a lot for a great project!

But I believe it could be even better with proper vector search engine under the hood :wink: 
I also believe that Qdrant is the best choice for that.

Here are some of the potential benefits it could bring:

- eliminate the need for explicit index rebuilding - Qdrant manages the vector storage in a way, that no matter updates or indexation - it always available for writes and searches.
- Scale more easily, decouple storage and encoders - it usually requires very different machines to serve encoding and search, so qdrant integration will solve that.
- possibility to make txtai stateless - I have noticed, that txtai uses `path: /tmp/index` for storing index and configuration, that could be a potential problem in case of e.g. k8s deployment, volume management could become too complicated. With dedicated storage backend it could be possible to place the whole state of the application into there.

This PR is an example of how Qdrant can potentially work with txtai, there are still some rough spots, e.g. saving offsets into the configuration: `self.config["offset"] += new`.

Would love to hear your thoughts,
Thanks!

title: Add scoring-based search
body:
txtai has had a scoring package since the initial 1.0 release. This package supports building a TF-IDF, BM25 or SIF index over a set of text. It is currently only used to build a weighted sentence embeddings vector with word vectors.

This issue will add a search method that enables searching the index. Two new parameters will be added.

- `terms` - if true, a list of document ids for each token will be stored
- `content` - if true, the original input documents will be stored

The logic for [TF-IDF](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tf%E2%80%93idf), [BM25 ](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Okapi_BM25)and [SIF](https://github.com/PrincetonML/SIF) should also be validated.

title: Modify embeddings search candidate default logic
body:
Currently, when the `content` parameter is enabled, similar() clause queries with no candidate parameter default to 10x the query limit. This can lead to inefficiencies for single similar clause queries as only query limit results are needed. 

The default `number of candidates` logic should be changed as follows:

- For a single query filter clause, the default is the query limit
- With multiple filtering clauses, the default is 10x the query limit
- Use the user provided `number of candidates`, if provided

body:
Add additional details to documentation regarding how embeddings indexes are saved as follows:

- How to save compressed indexes
- Details on syncing indexes with cloud storage

title: txtai Similarity really slow with ElasticSearch
body:
I've noticed when running ElasticSearch and txtai.pipeline for Similarity, the search (ranksearch) is very slow. When trying to search for 1 item, it can take upto 10 seconds.

The code I'm using is:
```
from txtai.pipeline import Similarity
from elasticsearch import Elasticsearch, helpers

# Connect to ES instance
es = Elasticsearch(hosts=["http://localhost:9200"], timeout=60, retry_on_timeout=True)

def ranksearch(query, limit):
  results = [text for _, text in search(query, limit * 10)]
  return [(score, results[x]) for x, score in similarity(query, results)][:limit]

def search(query, limit):
  query = {
      "size": limit,
      "query": {
          "query_string": {"query": query}
      }
  }

  results = []
  for result in es.search(index="articles", body=query)["hits"]["hits"]:
    source = result["_source"]
    results.append((min(result["_score"], 18) / 18, source["title"]))
  return results

similarity = Similarity("valhalla/distilbart-mnli-12-3")

limit = 1
query = "Bad News"
print(ranksearch(query, limit))
```

title: Improve embeddings performance with large query limits
body:
There is a performance issue when querying with large limits (>50) and content storage enabled. Queries can take 5-10 times longer than with content storage disabled in this scenario.

Reviewing the query plan shows:

```
explain query plan
SELECT s.id, text, score FROM sections s
LEFT JOIN documents d ON s.id = d.id
LEFT JOIN objects o ON s.id = o.id
LEFT JOIN scores sc ON s.indexid = sc.indexid
WHERE s.indexid in (SELECT indexid from batch WHERE batch=0)
ORDER BY score DESC LIMIT 100;
```

```
QUERY PLAN
|--SEARCH s USING INTEGER PRIMARY KEY (rowid=?)
|--LIST SUBQUERY 1
|  `--SCAN batch
|--SCAN sc
`--USE TEMP B-TREE FOR ORDER BY
```

**|--SCAN sc** is the main cause of this issue. 

Adding a primary key on the scores temp table updates the query plan to this:
```
QUERY PLAN
|--SEARCH s USING INTEGER PRIMARY KEY (rowid=?)
|--LIST SUBQUERY 1
|  `--SCAN batch
|--SEARCH sc USING INTEGER PRIMARY KEY (rowid=?)
`--USE TEMP B-TREE FOR ORDER BY
```

**|--SEARCH sc USING INTEGER PRIMARY KEY (rowid=?)** is now the plan and is much faster. The table scan on batch doesn't impact performance.

Additionally, the `INSERT_BATCH` statement should be split into two statements, one for inserting `indexid` and one for `id`. This prevents sending a bunch of NULL values. This marginally improves performance with 100s of inserts.

Both of these changes will work for new and existing indexes since it only impacts temp tables which are recreated with each db session.
